etymologies: early 16th century (formerly also as enterview): from French entrevue, from s'entrevoir ‘see each other’, from voir ‘to see’, on the pattern of vue ‘a view’

definitions: a meeting of people face to face, especially for consultation.
a conversation between a journalist or radio or television presenter and a person of public interest, used as the basis of a broadcast or publication

examples.text: a half-hour interview with the prime minister

shortDefinitions: conversation in which journalist etc. questions someone

definitions: an oral examination of an applicant for a job, college admission, etc.

examples.text: I am pleased to advise you that you have been selected for an interview

shortDefinitions: oral examination of applicant for job etc.

examples.text: he arrived to be interviewed by a local TV station about the level of unemployment

definitions: question (someone) to discover their opinions or experience

examples.text: all the customers interviewed were pleased to be getting a new bathroom

shortDefinitions: question someone to discover their opinions or experience

definitions: orally examine (an applicant for a job, college admission, etc.)

examples.text: he came to be interviewed for a top job
I was interviewing all last week

definitions: perform (well or badly) at an interview.
shortDefinitions: perform well or badly in interview
